title: How to Enable the Windows Subsystem of Linux (WSL)

steps.title: Open the Settings app
steps.content: Open the Settings app . Press the Start button and then the Settings gear on the lower-left corner of the menu.

steps.title: Select About from the left pane.
steps.content: Select About from the left pane. This will list a bunch of information about your computer.

steps.title: Ensure that your "OS Build" is above 14393.0.
steps.content: Ensure that your "OS Build" is above 14393.0. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Ensure that your "System type" is "64-bit operating system".
steps.content: Ensure that your "System type" is "64-bit operating system". [1] X Research source

steps.title: Click the Home button at the top-left of the Settings app.
steps.content: Click the Home button at the top-left of the Settings app.

steps.title: Click on For Developers on the left pane.
steps.content: Click on For Developers on the left pane. It's second from the bottom of the list.

steps.title: Click on the radio button next to "'Developer Mode".
steps.content: Click on the radio button next to "'Developer Mode".

steps.title: Confirm the warning.
steps.content: Confirm the warning. Windows 10 will display a warning for all of the implications that should be considered before turning Developer Mode on. Carefully read through all of these warnings and then press the Yes button.

steps.title: Navigate to the "Turn Windows Features On or Off" window.
steps.content: Navigate to the "Turn Windows Features On or Off" window. It can easily be accessed by typing in turn windows in the search bar.

steps.title: Wait for the list to load.
steps.content: Wait for the list to load.

steps.title: Check the box next to "Windows Subsystem for Linux (Beta)".
steps.content: Check the box next to "Windows Subsystem for Linux (Beta)". Scroll down to the bottom of the list to find it.

steps.title: Click on the OK button.
steps.content: Click on the OK button. Windows 10 will now start to download a bunch of files.

steps.title: When prompted, restart the computer.
steps.content: When prompted, restart the computer. Your computer will display a screen indicating that it's updating. This is actually Windows 10 setting up the Windows Subsystem for Linux.

steps.title: Open Bash.
steps.content: Open Bash. This is easily done by searching for bash in the search bar.

steps.title: Enter a username and password.
steps.content: Enter a username and password. Upon opening for the first time, Windows Bash will prompt you to create a username and password. Note that the username and password do not have to be the same as the username the password used to log into your Windows 10 account.
